clinical_study.brief_title: Ultrasound-guided Subclavian Venous Catheterization in Children
clinical_study.official_title: Comparision of Ultrasound-guided Supraclavicular and Infraclavicular Approach for Central Venous Catheterization in Children

brief_summary.textblock: The subclavian vein (SCV) is often the preferred site for central venous access. Ultrasound-guided SCV catheterizations with supraclavicular (SC) or infraclavicular (IC) approach have been proved to be useful in children. The investigators compared the success rate, number of attempts, time tocatheterization, and complication.

primary_outcome.measure: The duration for susscessful placement of needle into subclavian vein
primary_outcome.description: The time needed to place needle into the vein (from needle entry into the skin to aspiration of blood with syringe) was measured. When the duration was recorded as greater than 20 min, the procedure was defined unsuccessful and excluded from the analysis.

secondary_outcome.measure: The number of attempt for susscessful placement of needle into subclavian vein.
secondary_outcome.description: An 'attempt' was defined as each needle advancement to place needl into the vein. When the duration for susscessful placement of needle into subclavian vein was recorded as greater than 20 min, the procedure was defined unsuccessful and excluded from the analysis.

arm_group.description: supraclavicular: supraclavicular approach for subclavian venous catheterization
infraclavicular: infraclavicular approach for subclavian venous catheterization

intervention.intervention_name: Approach for ultrasound-guided subclavian venous catheterization
intervention.description: Each SCV catheterization was performed under ultrasound-guidance with supraclvicular or infraclavicular approach.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- central venous lines required patients
- children < 10 yr of age
Exclusion Criteria:
- inadequate ultrasound visualization of the subclavian vein
